baseline_groups.claim_summary: Mixing attitude (att_std) positively predicts multiple mixing behavior in the ambiguous domain, controlling for risk aversion, gender, and experience.
baseline_groups.notes: baseline/table1_ambiguous and baseline/table1/ambiguous are identical regressions (same coefficients, N=88). Coefficient is 0.066, p=0.27, not statistically significant.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: There is more multiple mixing in the ambiguous domain than in the risk domain, reflecting genuine ambiguity attitudes rather than noise.
baseline_groups.notes: Primary domain-level finding. Coefficient of -0.25 (p<0.001) on topic. This is the papers strongest and most central result.

global_notes: Two distinct baseline claims: (1) domain-level comparison showing more mixing under ambiguity vs risk (G2, highly significant), and (2) individual-level claim that mixing attitude predicts multiple mixing (G1, directionally positive but not significant). baseline/topic tests a different outcome (mixing_intensity_std) and is not a meaningful baseline. Table 2 cooperation analyses and domain t-tests represent separate claims.
